{{WikiProjectBannerShell|1= {{WikiProject Military history|class=start|Aviation-task-force=yes |Japanese-task-force=yes |Maritime-task-force=yes |US-task-force=yes |WWII-task-force=yes}} {{WikiProject Japan|class=start|importance=high|milhist=y}} {{WikiProject United States}} }} == Atomic bombs 'saved lives' == "If Hiroshima and Nagasaki have a positive side, it is that many lives were saved on both sides by the surrender of Japan before an invasion of the Japanese mainland was carried out." The above sentence represents a very old fasioned, even contemporaneous, view of the use of atomic weapons. Historiography of the past fifty years has shown what little truth there is in this theory. Therefore, I am removing it. [[User:Zackery the Fence|Zackery the Fence]] ([[User talk:Zackery the Fence|talk]]) 12:26, 24 April 2008 (UTC) :Perhaps you've not seen this page: [[Debate over the atomic bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki]]. The debate continues vigorously today. [[User:Binksternet|Binksternet]] ([[User talk:Binksternet|talk]]) 14:40, 24 April 2008 (UTC) ::That link is precisely the reason why that section is preposterous. It offers an entirely one-sided account and then just throws in that link at the end. I'd like to see somebody rewrite that section so it merely states what happened (bombs dropped, Japan surrenders) without turning it into an attempt at justifying anything. Leave that to the linked article. [[User:Midnight Bliss|Midnight Bliss]] ([[User talk:Midnight Bliss|talk]]) 03:07, 11 May 2010 (UTC) ==Grammar and surrender== I'm no expert when it comes to grammar, but the very title of this article does not seem right. Surely "Japanese Campaign" is more correct, but then that doesn't sound right as far as the subject matter in the article is concerned. Has anyone got any ideas for a less clumsy title ? I've changed 'September' to 'August' in the intro, because the Japanese ''did'' surrender in August, (on the 14th), see ''The Storm of War'' (ISBN 978-0-713-99970-9) by Andrew Roberts, 2009, page 577, para 2. True, the surrender was not formally signed until 2nd September, but as the old saying goes: "It was all over (in August), bar the shouting" ).
[[User:RASAM|RASAM]] ([[User talk:RASAM|talk]]) 22:20, 18 December 2009 (UTC)
